abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Mahaweli Ganga
            Development Project for Sri Lanka was unsatisfactory due to
            lower prices for rice, delayed implementation, and higher
            project costs. Institutional development objectives were
            only partially achieved and sustainability is uncertain.
            However, both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, farmer organizations need to be developed to
            assume more of the responsibility of the O&M (Operation
            and Maintenance). Second, institutional capacity needs to be
            strengthened in order to tackle environmental issues. Third,
            the Bank should organize a project launch workshop so that
            operational responsibilities can be clearly defined and
            understood by implementing agencies. Fourth, the Bank should
            have given more consideration to the ability of the project
            organization to implement all the activities envisaged.
            Fifth, the Borrower should complete major design works and
            surveys before credit effectiveness. Lastly, the Borrower
            should review procedures for tendering and awarding contracts.
